abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Forestry and
            Fisheries Management Project for Guinea was unsatisfactory.
            The project only achieved some of its objectives, its impact
            on institutional development has been significant,
            sustainability is uncertain, and the performance of the both
            the Bank and Borrower was marginally satisfactory. Several
            lessons can be learned from this project. First, a
            project's scope and implementing mechanisms must be
            tailored to the Borrower's design and planning
            capabilities, and the Borrower, as well as the ultimate
            beneficiaries, must really want the project and be closely
            involved in its preparation. Second, proper project
            management must be available before project start-up and
            assured at all times. Sound management is key, from the
            design stage through implementation, to the very achievement
            of project objectives. Third, forest management, including
            conservation, cannot be addressed in isolation of the
            management of surrounding areas. Finally, regarding
            fisheries, the issue of dramatically diminishing resources
            must be at the center of any operation in this sector and
            geographic area.
